What really makes this one worth watching is that it manages to poke fun at the rap scene and at Hollywood and at all the cliches, while still working every last one of them as elements of the flick. The rest of the cast turned in good performances, too, but we watched this for Harrison Ford and will watch it again for him. The man still has IT, and he shows it off in this movie.

One of the worst Harrison Ford flicks I have ever seen. For a seasoned actor like him, its strange that he should choose to work in such a movie. The plot digresses all the time and there is not much action or comedy in the action-comedy flick. Josh Hartnett sucks. Although Ford's quippy humour and his smirk breathe some life into the movie, its definitely not much reason for anyone to go and watch it.

review_title: Interesting Characters make "Hollywood Homicide" worth while

review_detailed_main: This movie was so bad it made me vote. I wish there was something less than a 1. I guess I have to vote now for some I like, as I trust IMDB. If this was a spoof, it failed miserably. If it was a real action movie, it failed miserably. If it was an attempt by a combination of never was and has been stars to prove that anything can get made, it succeeded. Geeez.

I just viewed this film and I enjoyed it. I think some people get to deep/profound and technical etc, it's only a film!

I was on a message board a while back with comments about a "Knights Tale". People were on about the costumes were not correct for the time in history and this and that.

IT'S ONLY A FILM AND QUITE AN ENJOYABLE ROMP, GOOD!!!

If we were talking about something like "Mutiny on the Bounty" or "Dances with wolves," we would expect correct costumes and details for that period, that's it!!!

What more can I say,

Dave..

I've got to say more because I need so many text words to get on the message boards;

To Market, To market, went my brother Jim,

Somebody threw some tomatoes at him,

Tomatoes don't hurt, they've got soft skin

But these Bastards did, they come in a tin!!!

Veteran (read: the old guy) Harrison Ford (as Joe Gavilan) really wants to make a big sale in his sideline real estate business. Rookie (read: the young dude) Josh Hartnett (as K.C. Calden) sidelines as a yoga teacher who really wants to be an actor. Mr. Ford likes to listen to Smokey Robinson, who appears as a cab driver. Mr. Hartnett yells "Stella!", and stages a version of "A Streetcar Named Desire", which you can see part of, in the last act. Ford beds lovely psychic Lena Olin (as Ruby), and eats Viagra. Hartnett beds various women, and eats bean sprouts. "Police detectives are different in Hollywood," they say...

Ron Shelton's "Hollywood Homicide" involves Ford and Hartnett investigating rap murder. Ms. Olin and Bruce Greenwood (as Bennie Macko) are strong supporting players. Fair to middling appearances are offered by Gladys Knight (not singing), Lou Diamond Phillips (gunning for Eddie Murphy), Mr. Robinson (a Miracle), Frank Sinatra Jr. (the son of), and Robert Wagner (in wet cement). Despite the involvement of some real rappers, the hip-hop music angle doesn't ring authentically. And, the film never finds the comic groove it's so obviously seeking. Things pick up toward the end, if you want to cut to the chase.

***** Hollywood Homicide (2003) Ron Shelton ~ Harrison Ford, Josh Hartnett, Lena Olin

review_title: I don't know why this gets bad reviews
review_detailed_main: It might not be for everybody, but I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. It's a guilty pleasure of mine that still has me cracking up when I watch it. Sure there will be people who overly critique this movie but for what it is, it's good. It wasn't made to be an academy award winning picture. If you like action comedies you'll like this one.

In reading others' comments/reviews, I noticed that those who "kind of" liked this movie were the ones who went to a free screening. Yeah, MY standards are lower @ a FREE screening also. However, I actually paid good money for this movie (well..my date did, actually), and I want the $7 and my 2 hours back!! So many things didnt make sense in this movie...tires were shot out at one point to stop a car...but later, a chase was required even though ample opportunity for the former presented itself. Lena Olin was a cliche. The plot was so simple I kept thinking "it can be this simple". And PLEASE dont FORCE me to listen to rap music!! My version of h***.

I suppose the idea of playing in a comedy must be intriguing to Harrison Ford probably because he doesn't get offered very many but its a shame he picked one so inane and pointless. Film is about an aging cop named Joe Gavilan (Ford) who moonlights as a real estate agent and no matter what crime was just committed he looks to try and sell a house. His young partner is K.C. Calden (Josh Hartnett) who is thinking very hard of being an actor and he reads lines from popular dramas and prepares for a role in a very small production of "Streetcar". One night a hip-hop club is shot up and the members of a popular group are killed so they decide to talk to Antoine Sartain (Isaiah Washington) who heads the label that signed the group. Meanwhile, Lt. Benne Macko (Bruce Greenwood) of Internal Affairs is looking to bust Gavilan because of their bad history together. Gavilan is dating a radio psychic named Ruby (Lena Olin) who also use to date Macko and she also helps Gavilan with clues with her psychic ability. The premise is interesting enough and there are many Hollywood cop jokes written into the film. My favorite is the cameo by Eric Idle who plays a celebrity caught trying to pick up a hooker! The film does a good job of showing how the cops of Hollywood are always thinking of doing something else since Los Angeles has so many opportunities for other employment. But the dialogue is so silly and inane that its hard to believe that someone like Ford would utter some of the things that he had to. Hartnett is especially drab and he doesn't show much flair for comedy but one thing I found surprising was that he doesn't show the charisma that he showed in "Black Hawk Down". He's stiff as a board which use to be Ford's manner. You know your stiff when Harrison Ford is more lively in a film! There is also to many cliches like Greenwood as the Internal Affairs Officer with a chip on his shoulder towards Ford. Haven't we seen that a hundred times? And I had to cringe when Ford is riding the girls bicycle and tooting the horn while riding through a mob of people. Film is ultimately too silly and pointless. Ron Shelton directed and he usually has a terrific knack for comedy but here the film comes across as very uninspired. Don't waste your time!

Hilarious - well written - well delivered.

I ignored the 'main coincidence', as it was *almost* too much.

The donut and the sale-of-the-house subplot had me laughing out loud.

As a 'have fun and enjoy yourself' rating: 10/10

The movie has one redeeming quality: of all the films shot in LA, this one is really SHOT IN LA: you get to see Los Angeles from the perspective of a local, where not everyone is a movie star, and where people live regular lives, at least as regular as one can live out there.

Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett are paired as the "buddy cops" whose job is to solve a nightclub murder of a rap group. In the course of doing so, they travel all over LA (the scenic shots make the movie worth watching all by themselves), and make sure that the investigation doesn't interrupt their "real" lives, which for Hartnett's character is his acting carer, and for Ford's, his endless search of real estate commissions.

The rap industry was poorly portrayed here, the music was second-rate (as rap almost always is when not done by rappers or when rappers are directed by non-rappers), and the plot was horribly contrived, but the actors are good and do the best they can with woeful material.

Without question, the plot's greatest strength is the many swipes it takes at LA culture in general, and the buddy-cop movies in particular. The heroes are not portrayed as quasi-supermen, but rather as a wheeler-dealer and an A-list actor trapped in the prison of regular jobs. Isaiah Washington did play the villain exceptionally well, but you'd have difficulty knowing this from the paucity of screen time he got.

The movie works, the plot works, and the acting works, but only works enough for no one to get fired. You won't regret watching this movie, but just barely. There are far better movies out there, but alas, there are also far worse. A true middle-of-the-road flick likely to be on cable for the next twenty years.

This movie would have worked better as a serious cop drama with the comic relief but instead it was a comedy that drew more laughs from embarrassment then humor. Josh Hartnett does a good job as an Ashton Kutcher mimic. And Dwight Yoakam was a surprise, as was Lou Diamond Phillip as the hooker/decoy. I did have to look at the credits to identify Gladys Knight because I was thinking she was maybe someone else I couldn't quite put my finger on, but there was no mistaking Smokey Robbinson. This movie also has a lot of other cameo shots throughout, such as Eric Idle, Martin Landau, Robert Wagner, Frank Sinatra Jr., and for those that are into hip-hop and rap, (sorry, I'm not) many an artist from that gene had cameos. Harrison Ford gave a good performance and had the only true laugh in the movie when he was in the interrogation room and did the "hip motion" while up against the two way glass. My feeling is that this is a good dollar rental or a movie for Spike TV. This is not the type of movie I'd spend a lot of money on, (I got my copy at Big Lots for $3) but I wouldn't avoid it either.

review_title: Hey, why not just call the film `Hollywood Hookers, Murderers, Rap Artists, Repo Men, Wannabe Actors, Drug Dealers, Bad Cops, Good Cops, Psychics, and Car Chases.'
review_detailed_main:
HOLLYWOOD HOMICIDE

GRADE: D+

For the past couple of years we've had a numerous amount of buddy-cop movies that attempt to be a `Lethal Weapon' or a `48 Hours' but don't even come close. That's usually because the two `buddies' don't have chemistry and the plot reeks more than a thirty-year-old turd. Those are just a couple of the problems in `Hollywood Homicide.'

Ford plays Joe Gavilan, a homicide detective that's up to his butt in debt and in his spare time dabbles in real estate. Hartnett plays his younger partner K.C. Calden, who is reconsidering being a cop and wants to be an actor, and in his spare time he's a yoga instructor. Things start to go awry when their investigation in a murder of a rap band leads them to a music CEO named Sartain (Isaiah Washington) and an unknown murderer (Dwight Yoakam). And at the same time, Internal Affairs officer Bennie Macko is trying to arrest Joe, who is dating Macko's ex-girlfriend Ruby (Lena Olin). Take all this and add about thirty-two subplots you get `Hollywood Homicide.'

The biggest problem with `Hollywood Homicide' is that it contains a long list of useless subplots that take up about half the film, leave no room for character development, and take us completely away from the main storyline. They throw the `Homicide' out the window! They might as well have just named the film `Hollwood'! They sure as hell deal with everything with `Hollywood' besides `Homicide`: hookers, murderers, rap artists, repo men, wannabe actors, drug dealers, bad cops, good cops, psychics, and car chases. Hey, why not just call the film `Hollywood Hookers, Murderers, Rap Artists, Repo Men, Wannabe Actors, Drug Dealers, Bad Cops, Good Cops, Psychics, and Car Chases.' If they would of went with that title I wouldn't have went into the theater expecting a good crime-solving movie, that dealt only with crime-solving, not that other mumbo jumbo.

What's up with Harrison Ford these days? Since 1998 all he's been doing is picking bad movies! With last year's `K-19: The Widowmaker' where he sported a really bad Russian accent, and 2000's `What Lies Beneath,' where he played a character that wasn't him at all. Here he plays a cop. He's played a cop in numerous film like `Witness' and `Clear and Present Danger.' But at least in those films he actually shed a little bit of charm and heroism. Here he just goes though the script like a zombie, showing not a glimpse of a real cop. And his supporting actors Josh Hartnett and Lena Olin don't help out at all. None of it feels real. It all seems like they have to be there, not that they want to be there.

It's not like Ron Shelton isn't a good filmmaker, he's made great films like `White Men Can't Jump' and `Cobb.' It's just that his lifeless script with Robert Souza packs no punches at all and takes no risks. When they were writing the script they were probably thinking seeing Ford ride a pink bicycle would be hilarious, but it's not.

Deep in this soulless piece-of-crap filmmaking, there lies the final half hour, which is the only reason I'm not grading this film any less. It's probably one of the best choreographed chase scenes on film. Only if the whole film had been that good.

review_title: Hollywood Homicide!? More like Hollywood Suicide! This movie kill itself! It's awful!
A Commendable Effort for a Difficult Task
review_detailed_main:
16 June 2003. It's not easy to make a semi-serious, comedy-cop thriller. Director, writer Ron Shelton (writer for Tin Cup and Bull Durham) took upon himself a very complex and difficult assignment trying to combine comedy with a rather serious, violent cop murder mystery. There were spots in the first half of the movie that seemed to lose action and momentum while the uneasy mix of crime drama and comedy required some brilliant skill and scriptwriting. The end result, "Hollywood Homicide" came out much better than the conflicting, confusing trailers of the movie (one a serious cop version and second trailer a comedy in the vain of Beverly Hills Cop).

The humor was above average, tinged with dry and cerebral humor not usually found in comedies these days. The interplay, the pushing the envelope in character development and character backgrounds were all good efforts at better, quality movie making. This movie was an entertaining and great first attempt by Ron Shelton who took risks with his material and found an fine balance between humor and story plotline that truly promises even better things to come.

Harrison Ford did great with his expressions, his sense of humor, and his letting go and enjoying, playing his part while Josh Harnett went a long for an enjoyable romp with a different kind of cop movie. While this movie wasn't perfect nor Oscar performing, it rates kudos for its experimental success in bringing more to the screen and braving new quality attempts at good movie-making. Seven out of Ten Stars.

This film couldn't be flatter. Even if you stomped it into the ground, went over it with a steamroller and landed a plane on it. Even as a bog-standard 80's direct-to-video, el-cheapo cop-thriller this would be the crap-de-la-crap. Hollywood Homicide (rubbish title!) thankfully and fortunately flopped big time in the summer of 2003. Though the audience who said 'no' to this were probably the same people who contributed to Bad Boys 2 (and equally terrible film from the same writer) being a success.

Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett play cops who moonlight as a real estate broker and yoga instructor. But Hartnett has aspirations to be an actor too (the irony is somewhat lost on him) and ends up yelling lines from A Streetcar Named Desire whenever he can. Oh stop it! My sides are splitting!

After a couple of rappers are gunned down in a nightclub they investigate. Ron Shelton manages to stretch out this incredibly NON-existent plot for very painful, very boring 115 minutes.

It tries to be funny, and thinks it is, but this arrogance only amplifies the tediousness of the rank-amateur script. I kid you not; I could have got a 12-year-old, hyper on Buzz Cola, to write something better and more professional.

Hollywood Homicide is Unbelievably bad. And, I never thought I'd say this, it actually makes Showtime look good in comparison.

The DVD is 2.35:1 anamorphic widescreen and Dolby 5.1 sound. There are extras but I couldn't care less coz this film is rotten.

I've debated this film for a while but because of the low review rating I've been put off. However It was the last day it'll be on Netflix so it's literally now or never.

I can't lie after the first 20 minutes I thought this just isn't the one and I'd just seen a really bad film so really wasn't in the mood. But it just kept picking up. It kept getting funnier as the film went on. It had that perfect mix of comedy and action. Was the definition of a proper early 2000's comedy action movie. The scene where they was both in the interrogation rooms was hilarious. I never knew Harrison Ford could be so funny.

I'll definitely be recommending this film to my friends. I'm just glad I actually got to watch it because if I didn't I'd have definitely never watched it.

this movie was not just bad it was so dull that it was really really bad. You could watch the first ten minutes and the last ten and be done- there is no need, really, no need to watch any of the rest. Unless you want to watch harisson get it on while eating a doghnut? and poor car chase, rubbish script, bad editing, awful soundtrack (watch out for the build up to the bits your supposed to laugh at but just arent funny, on any continent in any country). There is NO STORY!, except one that could be shown on an episode of Diagnosis Murder - and that is alot better! As I write this I actually realise that it is so dull that its not in the slightest bit entertaining, looks like it was made in the eighties but not influenced by anything good. There are so many worse films that are entertaining- if that makes sense, but this aint even bad enough to be that. Rubbish, rubbish, rubbish! Just needed to get that off my chest. It really is!

One of the best movies I've ever seen. It has it all: action, suspense, drama, and comedy that could hurt your gut.

The characters are so well developed, you know them inside out early in the film, yet no time is wasted on it. The movie keeps a good pace throughout. The casting was great, and everyone had their part down pat.

Harrison Ford is dynamite as Joe Gavilan. This is the new and improved Lethal Weapon. I've seen 14 year olds, 30 somethings, and 60 somethings all thoroughly enjoying this film. There are beautiful women to appease some but no gratuitous sex scenes. There is action, but no senseless violence. In all, I think this gives something to every type of movie watcher.

The humour is built into the movie and you don't have any Jar Jar Binks (or Joe Pesci as in Lethal Weapon) type characters that some require for humour. The characters actions and the results of those actions will leave you laughing harder than ever.

This is an immediate classic that would make a great series or even TV show if done with the same quality of this film.

This movie was such a formulaic, phone-it-in effort at making a typical Hollywood action film that it was almost a parody. There were about 20 mins of plot in this 2 hour movie (any Law and Order episode would blow it away). The rest was filler using sappy relationships, the usual police trouble with internal affairs (with a cop-out (heh, heh, get it) resolution) and the standard car chase seen at the end that went on so long, it began to get boring. Avoid this one.

review_title: Still having mixed thoughts on this one
review_detailed_main: Hollywood Homicide isn't a good film when you get right it down to it, nor is it a really bad one. Hollywood Homicide is a film that was butchered in the editing, script department and really lacks what it needed to be a hit in the summer time which is more action. The trailer pretty much gives away the plot which at some points in the movie goes haywire it seems like the studio was forcing Ron Shelton to give everything into the movie so it could be a big summer tent pole release but alas for a movie of this nature to be a big summer tent pole release in my opinion I would have changed a few things. Number one- replace the non acting Master P with the more rounded Mos Def (who can make any bad movie pretty enjoyable hence his work in Showtime). Number two - make the film R rated you can't make a movie about Gangster rappers and not have profanity, I mean honestly how many ganster rappers do you know that release clean CD'S by choice also add some nudity. As much sex as Hartnett was getting the film could have showed some T&A ! Number three - Give the very underrated Isiah Washingtion more screen time as the villain ! I think that version of Hollywood Homicide would have been good to release in the summer. Although Ford and Hartnett have good chemsitry the film that is made here would have been better suited as a winter or fall release. So like I said I still have mixed thoughts on this one I liked the film for Hartnett and Ford and the many cameo's and pop culture refernces but the story line and lack of action upset me. I give the film ** stars.

review_title: okay, so it's not Citizen Kane
review_detailed_main:
I actually thought this film was pretty funny. I love Harrison Ford, and here he stars in "Hollywood Homicide" as a cop/real estate broker. The film also features Josh Hartnett as his partner/fledgling actor, Lena Olin, Bruce Greenwood, Isaiah Washington, Keith David, Dwight Yoakam, Lolita Davidovich, Martin Landau, Master P, Lou Diamond Phillips, Gladys Knight, Smokey Robinson, Kurupt, Dre, with a cameo by Eric Idle, and also Robert Wagner.

Detective Joe Gavilan (Ford) and his young partner Kasey Calden (Hartnett) are assigned to a club slaying of a group of rappers. This brings them into the underside of the recording industry. Meanwhile, Gavilan is desperate to sell a house to get out of debt; later he tries to get the listing on the home of a producer (Martin Landau) in order to sell it.

His partner Kasey, whose father was a cop, isn't sure police work is for him. In fact, he's mounting a production of Streetcar in which he plays Stanley, and goes around practicing "STELLAAA".

The character of Gavilan is based on Robert Souza, a LAPD detective who also worked as a real estate broker ten years before retirement. The scene cuffed crook steals the gun from a patrol officer's belt and starts shooting it off in the parking lot actually happened during Souza's tenure.

I thought the chase scene, with Gavilan commandeering cabs, stealing bikes and whatever, was very funny, and the production of Streetcar was a good touch. Practically speaking, I know in New York City police officers can draw their guns in the city proper but are not allowed to use them because of pedestrians. I can't believe they don't have the same law in Los Angeles, yet every time I see a crime movie set there, people are standing on the street shooting off guns. This one was no different.

This is just a light comedy. Take it as such, and you'll enjoy it.

review_title: Horrible film, simply bad bad bad
review_detailed_main: This movie was the worst Harrison Ford film I have ever seen. I fast forwarded past many parts to get to the conclusion, which was equally stupid. The only cool thing about it was that you get to see Dwight Yoakum without his cowboy hat on. Dwight listen up my man, LEAVE THE HAT ON!!!!!! He looks like that weird looking brother of Ronnie Howard. You know the guy Ronnie throws into his films for three minutes to throw him some work. Seriously though, don't waste your time on this bomb. It's a bad as they come.

review_title: Why is it people have to be so critical...
review_detailed_main:
Why do people have to be so critical? Sure, this movie is no academy award candidate and may instead be a prime razzie award choice. But why is that cause for anyone to cut into it just because maybe "they" didn't get the point? It isn't!

The older, big name actors really show their age... Harrison Ford in particular. It really shows when we see him running. And Frank Sinatra Jr.! I hardly recognized him! But they weren't supposed to be their original selves... even big name stars age. I thought the fact of their againg was handled well.

This movie is poignant in places, it has some brief dramatic moments, has some passable action sets and is moderately funny throughout. It will need to toned down language-wise before it can be released for broadcast TV and a few of the steamier scenes will probably be cut, but it should draw a TV-14 rating.

The overall plot is reminiscent of those aimed at younger audiences where there is an obviously malevolent bad guy and unlikely heroes must save the day. The bad guys don't gloat and make threats of world domination, but they do hire killers and carry guns themselves. I did think the interaction between the Internal Affairs guy and his "minions" was a bit hokey though.

Bottom line here is that if you didn't like the movie that much, just write it off. Don't jump all over it like it was some virus or something. Okay? Personally, I would recommend it for anyone who enjoys comedic banter, overdone chase scenes, neat stunts and a fairly simple plot, by today's standards.

review_title: medals should be awarded for watching the whole film..............
review_detailed_main: This is a desperate film with no redeeming features whatsoever. Once again Harrison Ford's lack of comedic ability shines(!) through and reminds me of his rather inept performance in Working Girl. I rate Ford a fine actor but this role appeared badly chosen and maybe he is a bit limited now he is probably too old for fully fledged action roles. Regardless of whether the film is intended to be a self parody as some reviewers have maintained, surely the most important requirement is that it should entertain. Some of the humour is so forced and woeful that it borders on embarrassing, and the plot line jumps incoherently from one unlikely scenario to another. Little use is made of some potentially very useful cameo performers, and I, like most others found Josh Hartnett's performance quite baffling. His best acting seemed to be in Streetcar, and I'm sure it should have been his worst !! Again I like Hartnett, and perhaps blame should lay somewhere other than with the actors - as the saying goes "you can't make a silk purse out of a sow's ear" Makes you wonder whether the script offered by that bloke from Outkast could have led to a better movie.

review_title: contains several moments of absolute hilarity, generally good fun
review_detailed_main:
This movie is not wonderful or anything, but it contains several moments of absolute hilarity, and is generally good fun. Ford and Hartnett are brilliantly funny together in some bits. I recommend you check this out for some great laughs. Apparently IMDb is not a fan of brevity as they consider any review incomplete if it is less than "10 lines." But there's really nothing else I want to say about this movie. So what can I put here? How 'bout some cool quotes. Here are some great quotes from Joseph Conrad's novel "Heart Of Darkness":

1. "And this also," said Marlow suddenly, "has been one of the dark places of the earth." (p. 5)

Marlow delivers this comment about England just before he begins his tale about his adventures in the Congo.

2. # "I raised my head. The offing was barred by a black bank of clouds, and the tranquil waterway leading to the uttermost ends of the earth flowed somber under an overcast sky--seemed to lead into the heart of an immense darkness." --Marlow narrating

3."I tried to break the spell--the heavy, mute spell of the wilderness--that seemed to draw him to its pitiless breast by the awakening of forgotten and brutal instincts, by the memory of gratified and monstrous passions. This alone, I was convinced, had driven him out to the edge of the forest, to the bush, towards the gleam of fires, the throb of drums, the drone of weird incantations; this alone had beguiled his unlawful soul beyond the bounds of permitted aspirations." --marlow

Gee, this book is pretty racist ultimately... but well written i guess.

review_title: There's a movie in there somewhere
review_detailed_main:
It's not a comedy exactly, it's not a drama exactly, maybe it's an action-adventure movie? No, not exactly. A sexy-leading-men-toy movie? No, not that either - it's all of these, yet none of them completely enough to be satisfyingly any one of them.

Two cops more interested in their side businesses than taking care of business. A ridiculous car chase / fight scene. A bumbling comedy that takes off on tangents not even related to the storyline.

And poor ol' Dwight Yoakam: he sure is ugly isn't he? I know he can't help it, but it's like he works at it! What was it Sharon Stone said after dating him - "She'd rather eat a dirt sandwich". That personality comes out in every picture he's ever done. Look at Panic Room, The Newton Boys, Sling Blade, etc. 'We need a really ugly, balding *sshole. I know, Dwight Yoakham!'.

If it's on TV, and there's nothing else on, okay then suffer thru it. But do not pay money to see this garbage.

I saw a sneak preview for Hollywood Homicide this last Saturday the 7th at my local theater.

For the record, I am a huge Harrison Ford fan (note my name). I'm a little biased in my opinion of this movie, but only a little. It doesn't affect my judgement of a good or bad movie. I think Harrison Ford's character was his most fun to watch since Indiana Jones. I've always wanted to see Ford in a shoot-em-up cop movie and he delivers. But it's more than that, he plays it with a colorfulness and with a different humor than anyone had expected him to.

Very funny. Good buddy/cop movie. Good Ron Shelton movie. Good Harrison Ford movie. Good movie period.

Hartnett and Ford are both charming as hell, and make a good 'old guy and young guy' duo.

That's the entertaining part of the movie.

What cheapens it is the case that the story centers around.

By 2003, 'gangsta rap' was played out.

Master P is horrible, along with all of the cliche villains.

It would have been better just keeping the movie about their personal lives, without any case - over what they chose to go with.

It is still a fun watch.

5.3 is such a low grade for this movie, that it makes me wonder if I need to watch all of the other 5s on IMDb because they might be decent, as well.

People are way too hard on this film.

Just watched this on netfix, never heard of it, and now I know why! Action or comedy, quite frankly it's neither. Still quite shocked as why someone like Harrison Ford agree to do this pile of hooey. Nevermind!!

review_title: Not 100% successful. Or 50%, come to that.

review_detailed_main: I knew there was trouble with this picture when I first saw the previews & clips. I have been a Harrison fan & collector since 1980. With Ron Shelton the man behind Bull Durham I thought this would be a much better film. Josh needs to go back to school to learn to act. The script was bad. What the actors were asked to do with this film was embarrassing. HAD to be Rap the music in the film. Great, lets listen to that through the film. Right, news cameras would NOT in Hollywood know who would be getting a star on the Walk of Fame that day! Totally lame is the best way to describe this film. This all I wanted to say on the film

review_title: Eh, it was alright... I guess.
Save your money for another movie!!!
review_detailed_main:
Who in the world told Harrison Ford that this was a good role for him???

And Josh Hartnett...how does a 19 year old who can't fire a gun become a cop? Over used cliches plus zero character development and about 15 pointless music industry cameos equal a surprisingly bad film!!!

review_title: Somewhere in between Police Academy + Copland?
review_detailed_main:
Slim pickings in the weekly videos this week at our video shop, so went with this. It had Harrison Ford, it was about cops, couldn't be all bad.

"Hollywood Homicide" retells the story of Joe (Ford) a policeman who dabbles in real estate on the side. This storyline keeps the movie watchable. Joe's partner is the 2000's poor mans Keanu Reeves, Josh Harnett. The partners are working on the murders of a group of up and coming rappers. This is their focus, but they both have plenty happening outside of work. Joe needs to really sell a house or his finances are screwed and KC is about to star in a play which he hopes will see him get discovered. This means the story kind of gets torn in several areas, and no great detail or screen time goes into any of them. For this reason there's no great depth to the characters. The movie was still OK though, thanks to the real estate sideline and a few great cameos, including Eric Idle, Master p, Andre 3000 and more.

It was one of the greatest films I had seen before. If you didn't watch it before , I think you should see. In fact the names Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett make you know where you need to go. Enjoy!

I looked forward to seeing this movie, based on some very positive reviews I'd read, touting it's unique sense of humor in the context of the buddy-cop movie genre. Well, I was enjoying it for a little while, and there were some humorous moments early on, but it quickly became stale and formulaic and far too incredulous, suffering from way too many "happens to be" elements.

What I mean by that is...

Harrison Ford's girlfriend happens to be the former girlfriend of the nasty cop who's out to get Harrison Ford, who happens to be involved in an old situation with Dwight Yoakum's character, who happens to be the cop who killed Josh Hartnett's father (with Josh Hartnett happening to be Harrison Ford's partner). Harrison Ford happens to be an aficionado of Motown, and the crime witness happens to be the son of an obscure Motown singer, giving Ford the clue to find his whereabouts. Ford's girlfriend (was her name Ruby? I just didn't care to remember what the names were after seeing it) happens to be psychic and this convenient ability happens to be the only solution for them to come across the criminals to lead to the conclusion. I mean, I don't mind a deus ex machina if used cleverly, but this was ridiculous.

The more I think about it, the more preposterous this whole movie really was, and largely devoid of any real substance or creativity. As I said, early on there were hints that this could be a fairly unique character-based cop movie, but it just never paid off at all in that sense, and the cliches and "happens to be" plot proved to make this a big waste of time. A great cast, including a decent smaller part for Martin Landau and a cameo by Eric Idle, but I really have to wonder why someone like Harrison Ford would have wanted involvement in this junk.

4 out of 10 (and that was generous)

The purpose of a movie is to entertain, nothing else. This one fails badly. The dialogue is terrible. The movie is slow. The one good scene has a character never in the movie again. I could give you examples of why this film never achieves it goal, which isn't what you might think from the opening, but that would waste your time as much as this movie. Spend two hours watching clouds instead.

What a waste of talent. Why can't someone with Harrison Ford's experience refuse to participate in such lame dialogue as he did in this movie? It is reminiscent of the chimney speech from Gremlins. Now I understand Ford's lack of enthusiasm for the project when he was pitching it on Letterman last week.

Harrison Ford is a good actor, but I think that he isn't good in action movies and he's acting was quite bad. Whereas Josh Hartnett was brilliant and I hope he would make more action roles in his career.

Story of this film is very poor and that's why this movie has been unrated in all of movie posters. This movie isn't anything new and when you watch it you can guess what will happen next. There is some humour in this movie, but it didn't work at all.

After all movie was well directed and I give it 3 of 5.

review_title: Cute movie, until the last 1/2 hour
Harrison Ford shouldn't try anymore comedy.
review_detailed_main: "Hollywood Homicide" is not much different than almost every other "mismatched buddy-cop" picture that have been made over the years. It tries to be "Lethal Weapon" meets "Rush Hour," which sounds like a great combination. But it just doesn't hit the mark. While Harrison Ford is usually a very believeable and dependable actor, he must take some of the blame for this lackluster flick. He has absolutely no comedic instincts. He is probably trying to break out of his leading man roles. He is, afterall, getting a little too old for those. Comedy seems like a good idea. DeNiro's been doing it, but Ford just can't pull it off. Josh Hartnett is better, but his character is so one dimentional that he's borderline boring. I was really disappointed with this movie overall because it had so much potential. It's funny how the trailers at the theatre were edited to make this movie look like a comedy, but the TV spots have action written all over them. It's not that any movie has to be one or the other, it's just that this one is all over the place looking for a home. Ford is good at the physical comedy, but when it comes to dialogue, he falls flat. Don't bother to go to the theatre, wait to rent this one on DVD.

This is like the worst movie ever, I feel sick. TERRIBLE acting and story. I never commented any movie in here before but I just had to warn everybody about this movie. Those of you who voted 5 and up: I feel sorry for you guys, honestly.

It got fat. He was soooo cute. I love me some vintage Josh. Pearl Harbor was the perfect Hartnett face. He's still real cute here. The movie is only so-so but Josh is still in his cute prime. I'm not a hundred percent he was ever a brilliant actor, he's ok. I actually thought he was going to be a major movie star after Pearl Harbor but it didn't happen. I'm not sure if that's because of his acting or his choice of projects? Idk. In this movie, I thought he could have exercised a little more comedic chops here. He wasn't terrible but not seasoned. But he has enough charm to get by, at least enough for me. I actually was more surprised by Ford being funny. Wasn't expecting that. But always love me some of that dreamy Josh face:)

it sucks and that says it all awfull story, awful acting everything is just pathetic i rented the movie for a night with my friends. after an hour of watching we throw it away...we didn't even wanted to see how it ends...we didn't care. i saw a lot of bad movies that i beared to watch till end but this one was too much my recomandation....don't go on cinema, don't rent it and god hope don't buy it.harrison ford better stick with playing indiana jones or a fugitive or anything then a cop or a salesman. the other guy better become a bus-boy or anything else than an actor(i didn't even learn his name ...didn't worth it). I give this film a great 1(ONE) and say that AWFUL IS NOT ENOUGH!

This may be one of the best Josh Hartnett movies ever. But not such a great one for Harrison Ford, it was to out of character for him and not in a good way. But then again Hartnett was out of character to. But in a very good way. I would really recommend it! I totally loved it!!!

review_title: I guess we've seen that before
review_detailed_main: Being listed as a comedy I would say there is remarkable little to laugh about in this movie. Both lead stars provide us with a totally uninspired performance and the story has nothing to offer either. Actually, I'm still wondering whether the side-story of Joe Gavilan (Harrison Ford) trying to sell some real-estate was supposed to be funny. This is your regular buddy-cop movie but it doesn't come close to the best in class, "Lethal Weapon". The action scenes also bring nothing new, we've all seen that 1000 times before. I watched this movie in two parts and I had to force myself to put the DVD back in the player and watch the second part. All in all I give it 4/10. Only watch it when you've got nothing else to do and are really really bored.

review_title: Ford is back in the saddle!
Indiana Jones... to this? What happened?
review_detailed_main:
Harrison Ford's career is officially down the tubes. I knew this from the opening scene where we scene a wannabe thug with all gold teeth talking to a once well respected actor. Wow, all I can say is that 2 Fast 2 Furious was far more enjoyable then this stinker.

I gave the movie a 4 just because the final 10 minutes kept me from falling asleep... if you decide to spend your money to go see this, heaven forbid, just show up for the last 10-15 minutes, its the only entertaining scene in the entire movie.

... Only with this one, I don't think there was truthfully that much to debase, in the beginning...

A 'Keystone Cops' setup with someone as grizzled as Harrison Ford just doesn't work. Can you imagine the man himself pedalling real-estate? I wouldn't have thought so; he's far too 'gruff' and straight-down-the-line for that. As an actor he's a victim of the iconic roles he made famous; I'm sure he has a greater 'range' than some people will allow, but "Hollywood Homicide" is far too limp a vehicle for him to properly demonstrate it. Given a better script he could well play capably against type, but handing a non-comedian material too lame for Adam Sandler and expecting 'magic' to result is beyond even his talents. Each of you reading this review; think of the performer who generates the most chuckles within you... Got them? Right; well, I don't care who they are, even THEY couldn't have made "Hollywood Homicide" - as it stands - funny. Also, for something billed as an action-comedy, your pulse will likely be as constant as the expression of consternation that clouds your face...

It's Hollywood, alright; because you have trouble believing some of the actors here fit their roles. On that same note, why does Lou Diamond-Phillips have to consistently resort to playing transvestites in order to get work, these days????!! Midway through the running time, it gets to the point where there are so many extracurricular activities, we lose interest in what little actual 'plot' there is; so if the point is meant to be that these people aren't fully committed to the job they're doing, it's a case of life imitating art. The characters and actors appear sometimes disinterested, and ultimately that's how I felt, too.

review_title: I paid a dollar for it and I overpaid.
review_detailed_main:
What a waste of time and money.

I wasn't expecting much and I got exactly what I was expecting and nothing more.

If you have time to waste in your life, than this is perfect.

If you have important stuff to do like - shine your shoes, cut the grass, count grains of salt or maybe wash your hair...then by all means - take care of those important issues before watching this movie.

I thought of counting seconds in order to make sure that each one follows the next...but instead I decided to put this in the VCR and press play...I made a mistake.

review_title: Could have been a lot worse, could have been a lot better
review_detailed_main: I came out of this movie baffled --- I think I spent most of the time baffled. The entire internal police investigation thing I still do not understand (sharing of funds?) and Madame Cleo's and Psychic Ruby's characters (Lolita Davidovich and Lena Olin) looked so much alike the group of us spent the entire movie thinking they were the same character posing as one as part of the police sting and Joe's character didn't realize it. (we didn't even realize it until the credits rolled!) The bad cop and the donut scene was hilarious ... Josh Harnett needs to learn to stop acting without squinting and Bruce Greenwood was wasted (what a fine actor!) The best part of the movie were the cameo roles ... you will be laughing to yourself "was that who I think that was???" (and yes it was!) Not a bad was to spend a hot afternoon at the multiplex that has air conditioning ... just make sure you have lots of junkfood!

Hollywood Homicide is definitely a movie everyone should see !!!! I adored it !!Josh Hartnett and Harrison Ford make a superb team and they're really funny. What I don't understand is how critics from popular newspapers or magazines can be so severe in their judgment. I mean I saw awful comments on Hollywood Homicide . Some very insulting like : an humiliating comedown for Ford or Harrison and Josh Hartnett have about as much chemistry as a pair of wet socks!!! I know that everyone have their opinion but frankly I can't understand why they published articles full of insults about this movie. So everyone! Don't believe all you read about Hollywood Homicide and go see the movie. After that you'll be able to have your OWN opinion ...... personally I give it 9.5/10 !!!

review_title: Homicide is right, this movie is dead
review_detailed_main: This time you should believe the terrible things that the critics are saying about this bomb. Why Harrison Ford would act in this movie is beyond me; certainly not to raise money to feed Calista Flockhart. The movie was a like a game of Jeopardy played by stupid people, no answers for many questions. Once again, I want my money back.....this movie sucked.

review_title: Surprisingly unfunny and uninvolving film - deserves it's poor box office and reviews

review_detailed_main:
I spent an hour waiting to find anything I liked. This movie is another example of an emerging trend in Hollywood: find a name star(s) to save a dismal project.

I guess I've seen too many cop pictures, but the whole thing here is old. I can think of at least 6 flicks with a similar plot line...throw in a couple kinks and bingo! you have a great movie.

Wrong!

The formula needs rethinking.

review_title: Both actors didn't act, Josh looked embarrased to be in this
review_detailed_main:
Harrison Ford is a great actor, however he should stick with "Jack Ryan" & "Indiana Jones", something is missing when his character is supposed to come across as funny- Josh Harnett can do better, & should have done better in this film.

However together you wish their characters would have been killed off after the first five minutes (which were the best 5 minutes of the whole movie)! It was embarrassing to see these two fine actors turn in such weak performances.

I can't believe I paid $7.00 to see this flick!

The movie has great gaping holes in it that are never explained fully such as: why does the fourth member of the rap group suddenly becomes a suspect and is arrested? How do they tie in the record label executive into the murders? All the detectives have for evidence is "hearsay". The implausability of the movie truly distracted from the performances and I never could buy into it.

The only reason to rent this film would be to see the chase sequence. It's truly fascinating and it's hysterical to watch Harrison wheel and deal on the phone (a la Hollywood) all the while cars are being wrecked around him.

Wait for rental.

What was Harrison ford thinking when he signed to this? Despite all the hype I felt myself short changed in the end.Though it is admittedly light hearted fun the movie went no where fast. The movie fell flat. I had high hopes while looking at the previews. I guess like books don't judge a preview on star power. There was no chemistry between Ford and Lena Olin. No chemistry either with Josh Hartnet as Ford's partner in the police force. The cameos of Smokey Robinson and Robert Wagner was a waste of time. It was an embarrassing mess that should not have been done in the first place. The plot was silly and the acting average. All in all it was a pretty lame movie.

This is a pretty good movie. It stars Harrison Ford, Josh Hartnett, Lena Olin, Bruce Greenwood, Isaiah Washington, Lolita Davidovich, Keith David, Master P, Dwight Yoakam, Martin Landau, Lou Diamond Phillips, Kurupt, Frank Sinatra Jr., Choppa, Krazy, Magic, T-Bo, and Robert Wagner. I was so surprised about Phillips. His character is so convincing! This is a serious thrilling comedy actioner with lots of things happening all the time! There are many moments where Harrison Ford is just hilarious and a lot of other things in the film are as well! The action is really great and I loved the chase near end! If you like Harrison Ford and/or any of the actors mentioned above then I strongly recommend Hollywood Homicide!

Those were the worst opening credits I've seen in a movie for ages, who would have guessed things wouldn't get any better. The basic plot could have worked well if they had a good script writer and two lead actors that gelled; unfortunately both gave terrible performances. Avoid this piece of rubbish.

This movie is sort of a dramady that doesn't quite work either way. Harrison Ford is good as always as the veteran cop. Josh Hartnett,though, is miscast and needs acting lessons just like his character. Hartnett inability as an actor is more evident here when paired up with the far superior Ford. Of the other characters, only Lena Olin stands out as the psychic. The story is all over the place not knowing whether or not to be serious or funny. Either way, it does not justify a 132 minute running time. When the audience is way ahead of the characters who the killers are and it takes them so long to catch up, you know you are in trouble. The movie is also full of unnecessary subplots that inexplicably are supposed to join with the main plot at the end. Overall, a watchable mixed bag, 5/10.

review_title: No offense to anyone but this was awful!
review_detailed_main:
The acting was just horrible, so was the story line! Even I was getting annoyed with the constant cellphone thing! it wasn't that funny either, but I guess you have to give the people credit for trying so hard. I feel sorry for the actors when this movie was looked down on by critics.

Acting: 1/5 Storyline: 2/10

Over all: 3/10

I didn't really even want to rent it...

review_title: Fun, fast and Ford with Hartnett are double barreled
review_detailed_main:
This Harrison and the 'kid' movie I was roundly ignoring for a couple years. I had no idea that it was as fun and terrifically acted and directed as it was. I made an assumption about Josh and I was wrong. I saw the billboards in Los Angeles when I lived there and somehow I was interested in it for a moment then convinced myself that I didn't want to see it. After I bought it on DVD, I was driven by the story. Harrison Ford was a good cop with some trouble and a great real estate man on the side. Josh being an exercise instructor with a tunnel vision for perfecting his craft in Hollywood, and on the side a cop. Joe (Ford) is helping his young partner out in a pinch, along the way, (subplot), the kid learns some eye-opening stuff. This had some new and old school players that made it all mix right together. I have seen this several times and amongst the action there is a scene in a Mustang that kind of just sticks with me, in the aftermath they handle things as though they are just on the top of their best game!

This was a sleeper hit for me and unexpected action drama with a good slice of comedy.

Recommended Highly for Hartnett and Ford fans.

I'm not going to take too much time blasting this movie because it doesn't really deserve the effort. The only thing I can really say is I sat through this movie for 45 minutes then got up and walked out. That's how dreadful this thing was. There was nothing funny or exciting about any portion of this movie. When I looked at my watch I would have sworn I had been in there close to two hours, not the case. So if you haven't seen this movie, I suggest not wasting your time on this thing.

review_title: Casual laughs and a mad chase
What Harrison Ford movies are almost never
review_detailed_main: This movie is terrible. There is no other word to describe it. The movie is riddled with plot holes, and only because the filmmakers wanted to keep it under 90 minutes. This is the type of movie where a 7 or 8 year old might like it because there is shooting and gunbattles, though they are poorly executed, but anyone who actually pays attention to films will be disgusted by the film's many mistakes. In short, don't go seeing this film expecting to see a well-written, well executed film, and certainly don't bother renting it either, and just watch it on HBO, like I did. In conclusion, a terrible film not worth your time unless the only other option is drilling holes in your head, which actually might be more enjoyable.

review_title: Dull in a way that makes you wonder if they were trying to be this bland intentionally.
Boring mostly, not even a good comedy!
review_detailed_main: Harrison Ford was not up to par in this movie, maybe he's just getting old and grabbing at any type of movie to appear in. I've seen some movies of his that were comic but to me, this was a bomb. All that running around doing real estate seemed to me silly.

but rather disappointing. During the first half of the movie, I squirmed in my seat, checked my cell phone messages (the sound was off...trust me), checked my watch...this was BORING. The action picked up a little in the second half and there were a few laughs, but in general, this was not the movie I hoped it would be. One good thing I can say is that at least Harrison Ford was not cast with a nauseatingly young girl as his love interest this time! Lena Olin, on the other hand, was not give much to do...there were lots of cameos (eric idle did make us laugh just by appearing on the screen...not many actors can do that) but in general, this was a lackluster movie...worth seeing at a matinee or maybe as a rental...on the other hand, it's summer, and there generally aren't that many good movies out in summer anyway <sigh>....

This movie in my opinion is the best movie of 2003. It has just about just about everything in it, action, drama, suspense and plenty of laughs. I was having a bad day when I saw this movie but after I walked out of the theatre, I felt better. Harrison Ford plays a little bit of a different role in this movie. His role as Joe Gavilan is a no nonsense cop who acts really tough in the movie. I strongly recommend this movie though, with it's great action and car chases, it is worth it. I give it 10 out of 10.

If i wasn't such a complete Josh Hartnett fan, i wouldn't be saying this but i pretty much enjoyed this movie. It had its funny moments, but some of the time it was just horribly unfunny. When Harrison says "F u very much" i have to admit it was funny. I'm sorry to say this but...Harrison Ford is getting too old for buddy cop movies like this... I would've rather stared at Josh Hartnett for the length of the film than see Ford have a sex scene with some woman.

I give it 6/10 stars.

I expected a lot more out of this movie. I thought the teaming of Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett would be very interesting and the movie had been lauded as such a great one. I was absolutely disappointed and disgusted that I wasted my time and money to go see it. There was way too much swearing (right from the get-go) and it seemed as if it couldn't decide whether it was a cop flick, a buddy flick, a music flick, or just a throw-as-many-cameos-in-as-you-can flick. There were *some* funny lines and the movie did get good (finally) in the last 15 minutes, but basically, it was a complete waste of time and money. I didn't care for the writing (including the one dimensional characters, the lack of substance, the loose ends, and lame premise -- all of this happened in a few days? What's up with that?). The directing was okay (although not first rate). And I sincerely wanted to give Josh a haircut the entire length of the movie (what was the purpose of that 70's style anyway?). Bottom line: If you are interested in a real good story or even good scenery, don't waste your efforts to go see this movie. Both thumbs way, way down for this disappointing venture.

Yerok 7890 is right on! This movie is a mess! What amazes me is the good reviews from other IMDB reviewers. Anyone who wrote a good review for this movie must live in a cave and never seen a quality movie before. I gave it a one only because I was in a good mood that night. A TOTAL DISASTER.

this movie was dissapointing and I went expecting very little in return. I think I barely cracked a smile at the half-hearted jokes and stale "crusty-old cop vs. idealistic young, scrappy cop" routine.

the funniest bit is at the end, however, so you got that going for ya.

Kinda predictable, but worth a few laughs, especially with the dirty jibes to Hollywood. Ford displays his anger well and Hartnett gave a worthy performance at the last arrest. Light hearted fun overall. 7.5

Some nice chicks in the yoga class.

review_title: Don't kill yourself to see 'Hollywood Homicide'

review_detailed_main: This movie could have been good but the story has far too many sub-plots and the main theme gets lost. Is it Buddy-cop movie, is it a you killed my dad movie, is is a murder movie...it goes on and on. Not horrible but not worth the time.

review_title: Tries to poke fun at the genre, but can't help being apart of it
review_detailed_main:
Ron Shelton seemed to have the notion that he could make a cop movie, obviously different from Dark Blue (which is the better movie), by using a strategy seen similarly in last year's Showtime with De Niro and Murphy. That one had laughs since each actor had their own personalities to add to the lengths the humor could take them. In 'Homicide', Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett can only be as funny as the script allows them to be, and sometimes laughs come unintentionally instead of by true skill.

Shelton does try to give the genre a bit of a gear change- Ford and Hartnett play cops who also have part-time jobs on the side, Ford a real estate broker who's been lagging in sales, Hartnett a yoga instructor and wannabe actor who seems to have less skill in the later, though more ambition for that than his cop job. They're assigned a case involving a murdered rap group, which includes a record company and the main producer (Isaiah Washington), who may or may not be working different angles.

If any working comedy comes in the movie it's in small, ridiculous doses that may be funnier to a viewer depending on sense of humor, for instance their is a running gag involving cell phones, which may be funny if someone else in the theater doesn't have a cell phone that goes off during the scene (it unfortunately happenned to me at the screening I went to). Or in the climax in which the thrills are done with a quasi Lethal Weapon feel, where one can see Ford's frustration and relentlessness as a good thing or a bad thing. When the credits rolled up for Hollywood Homicide I concluded to myself that I had seen an unfortunately average cop-buddy piece, one that took itself too seriously to be a comedy, and took too many pot shots at the exagerations that could be placed in such a movie. Perhaps Ford can be good in comedy if he gets the right direction (he helped ease some of the tension in 6 Days, 7 Nights) and script. C+

The title of this film is misleading. Ron Shelton's satirical version of the L.A.P.D. Hollywood division is right on target. Most viewers go to see this film, probably, with the wrong idea in mind. This is a tongue-in-cheek account of these two so very different detectives that are real life partners on the streets of Los Angeles.

First of all, the idea of Det. Joe Gavilan selling real estate on the side to make ends meet is hilarious. At the most intense moments of the film he is interrupted by phone calls from prospective home buyers, or sellers; it is not to be believed! Also, the idea that K.C. Calden, played by Josh Harnett, can't shoot the target and his partner has to do it for him, goes over people's minds. That part of the audience misses the point of the satire on the genre cleverly executed by director Ron Shelton.

This is a role Harrison Ford might have been waiting for. He is in top form here. He looks the part. His Joe Gavilan is a man who has seen better days already and is ready for retirement. Harrison Ford will always be identified, perhaps, with action films. He proves here that he can play comedy as well as anyone else without making the character looks stupid, or out of place.

Josh Harnett on the other hand was a surprise in this film. He holds his own against Mr. Ford. They make a goofy pair wherever they go. The idea he is an aspiring actor in a town full of wannabes is hysterical. That he can teach yoga to a class full of female students is not one's idea of what macho police detectives should be like.

The casting of Lena Olin as Harrison Ford's love interest was very clever. She's a good actress whose career has been somehow limited by the choices she has made, probably, but she is radiant in this film. Bruce Greenwood, Lolita Davidovich and Keith David round up the cast, but obviously it's the Ford show all the way. They seem to have had a great time while filming it.

The movie was "OK". Not bad, not good, just OK. If there was anything else in the theater this would be skipped by far. Sadly, Fast and Furious 2 also stunk, but I'd rather see this than FF2. :) If you have a fetish for harrison ford or that other young punk, this will be a "cute" movie for you. Personally, I'd wait for HBO or Blockbuster.

I went to this movie not knowing what to expect, so I wasn't disappointed. The character interaction is great, and there are some great performances. However, I suspect that some of the story was left on the cutting room floor because - even though both we the audience and the protagonists know what is going on - the characters never get enough information to build a good case. Or maybe I just missed something.

However, even if it was great movie, it wouldn't have been worth the $7.25 I paid to see it - it is not a big screen movie (not that there is anything wrong with that).

So, wait for the video.

Hollywood Homicide wasn't exactly what you would call fantastic cinema, but it had some worthwhile moments. Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett actually worked very well as a team. Hollywood Homicide had a few twists to it that made it different than the usual cop movies. Among K. C.'s 'Streetcar Named Desire' storyline, there were other parts that made the film reasonably amusing. I would suggest seeing this movie if you are in the mood for just a fun sort of film.

Hollywood Homicide: 4.5/10


I went to see 28 Days Later, but the next screening wasn't for two hours, so decided to watch Hollywood Homicide instead. This was the old cop/new cop storyline, with Ford as the veteran and Josh Hartnett as the young cop who also wants to be an actor. Like with "Just Married" from earlier this year, most of the funny moments were shown in the trailer, leaving a lot of dead time. Thankfully, Ford's acting made those parts watchable, but this was a poor role for Ford, who continues to slumber in Hollywood, taking mediocre roles like this instead of shining with better scripts. Hartnett is almost as green as an actor than his cop character was in the movie, somewhat charismatic, but not very good. Most supporting actors were weak, and the main strength of this movie was a really good chase scene through Hollywood at the end. I only laughed a few times, so this didn't really work for me.

review_title: Not your average buddy cop flick.
Odd cop film pairing doesn't work
review_detailed_main:
Hollywood Homicide starring Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett in an odd pairing and unrealistic cop crime comedy drama. This film didn't work as it film tried too hard to pair an older character with a younger one. The film did include some decent action sequences. Instead of making a memorable movie that could have stood out because of the wisdom, integrity or heart of the two men, in the end, all we get is a typical cop movie.

The film is labeled a comedy and does have comedic elements, but a lot of it is very forced. Examples would be of an awkward interrogation scene, and another scene where Harnett is chasing a suspected criminal where the criminal is shown going into a lake to try and dodge Hartnett. They weren't funny, and came off as awkward and time wasting. Hollywood Homicide did flop when it was released in theaters and one can see why. Several of the trailers were misleading, and the PG-13 rating to the film hurt it's chances, also of being a better film.

review_title: I could have maybe gone for 2.5, but it's not worth rounding up to a 3
review_detailed_main:
There's nothing to spoil so don't worry about that.

This thing was hanging onto about a 4 until the last 40 minutes; everything after that point drops it to a 2. Part of me is debating whether I should be more generous, but the gap doesn't seem big enough. It kind of just ran into a wall and fell down hard.

It's pretty bad but not the worst ever. Really there's no reason to waste my time or your time on it and I just felt compelled to contribute to the score. Unfortunately I am not doing both in reaching for this ten line minimum.

Be assured that reading this was less boring than the film it reviewed.

Hollywood HOMICIDE is an utter disaster, considering what Ron Shelton is capable of doing. This film is supposed to be a buddy comedy but it's mystery is a clichéd mess and it's not funny. Ford and Hartnett are both great actors but fail to generate much chemistry and the script is incoherent tripe. If you want to see a much better film by Shelton watch DARK BLUE with Kurt Russell in one his finest performances. Hollywood HOMICIDE is bland, stale, and uninteresting despite valiant efforts by Ford and Hartnett. There are a few fresh moments but ultimitely this film is a waste of time. Hollywood HOMICIDE-** out of 4.

review_title: Two cops working on solving a homicide of some really bad guys and got them into all kinds of trouble (I think)
review_detailed_main: This movie is hard for me to summarize because it was so confusing. Two cops were working together on a homicide, one older (Ford) and a younger partner. Frankly I had difficulty following the plot. All this business of selling his house and the romance (?) with Ruby got in the way. I didn't even get it. Maybe it's just me but I thought this was one of the worst movies I have ever seen and I couldn't believe an actor of Harrison Ford's caliber would even consider being in this movie. Normally I love Harrison Ford and was looking forward to watching it on late night TV However, it was awful. When it was over (and I wish I hadn't stayed until the end) I felt like someone was kidding me. This wasn't really Harrison Ford, was it? So sad! I'll grant you he doesn't look his age but he also wasn't acting his age. Come on - 60 is 60. Let's have a little dignity.

review_title: oh dear...this film really didn't work!
review_detailed_main:
Both Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett are truly great actors...but watch Hollywood Homicide and you'll question whether Indiana Jones, Patriot Games or Pearl Harbor (which I think is a great film) ever really happened! Neither actor is convincing in either tough detective mode or amusing blunder time.

The precedence of rappers in the film too obviously markets it towards the MTV audience and yet still fails to deliver. Complete lack of substance, way too long, a parody of itself, this film is one of the worst films I've ever seen...although the scene where Harrison Ford steals a kids bike and battles with downtown traffic was so hilarious it almost made me forgive the rest of the film for being so bad...but only almost.

An embarrassing film on the resumes of a Hollywood great and an upcoming successor. Why oh why did they agree to do this film?

this is a good movie. it had action and comedy, the two ingredients that i love in a movie thats not scary, but they dont even make those anymore, usually they too are funny. This movie has a good spin to it, i didnt expect much really, but i got way more than i paid for, especially saying that it was a sneek preview.:)

Greetings again from the darkness. My screening was not billed as a "Sneak Preview", but I hope it was. Now director Ron Shelton can go back and edit this mess into a real movie. This is a waste of time and money. A very intriguing cast wasted in a joke of a buddy picture. This has to be the simplest genre to film. All you need is a bit of chemistry between your leads and then copy "Lethal Weapon" or "Bad Boys" or any number of decent films in the past. Not sure what was happening here other than Harrison Ford trying to latch onto the soaring career of teen heartthrob Josh Hartnett. Both look uncomfortable and talentless in this ridiculous flop. Lena Olin tries to add a touch of class and Dwight Yoakum, Martin Landau, Sinatra's son, and Isiah Washington all have their moments. Lolita Davidovich survives the best. Now on to Bruce Greenwood, who has no talent and has continued his streak of bad films despite being cast along some major film talent. ATTENTION HOLLYWOOD: STOP CASTING THIS GUY. IT IS SUICIDE TO YOUR FILM.

review_title: A good, but not great movie.
no comedic chemistry between Ford and Hartnett
review_detailed_main: i was so disappointed with this movie.a buddy cop film with Josh Hartnett and Harrison Ford should have had potential,shouldn't it?Ford and Hartnett play two cops who are partners and who also have second hobs to make ends meet or to have financial independence.they are called in to investigate the murder of a rap group.hilarity should ensue,right?if by hilarity,you mean endless yawning,then yeah,hilarity ensues.this one really hurt my brain.it was agonizingly boring to the nth degree.i think i saw this at a cheap theatre,but what ever i paid was exactly that amount more than i should have paid.i think they should have payed me to see this thing.i think the real problem with this movie,is their is no chemistry(the comedic kind) between Ford and Hartnett and that pretty much sinks the whole movie.for me,"Hollywood Homicide" is a 3/10

review_title: Stink-A-Roo = Harrisons worst - Harnett awful = TERRIBLE MOVIE
review_detailed_main:
Stnk - A - Roooooo Hollywood Homicide is pure garbage. The only reason i watched the whole thing is because im paralyzed, and i couldn't switch the channel myself in bed, lol.

This movie shows you that you can create a junky movie with a bunch of big name stars and it will still make money.

I paid $1 at a flea market for it, and i want my money back! ha ha ha Everything about this movie was pure trash. It was too long, filled with boring stuff i didn't even care about.

The acting is awful... everyone was bad except the black cop, i liked his tiny roll.

Every situation was so fake, it was like the writer was in 12th grade.

Harrison Ford reminded me of a old guy trying to act cool. His part was supposed to have comedy, but it was so fake that it just made him look dumb.

Josh Harnette was absolutely awful. He should never trust the guy who wrote his part again. His character was not even likable. I personally would have seen his character killed off in first 5 minutes.

This movie was a waste of time. skip it, watch anything else that looks exciting to you on TV.

I'd give it a 3, just because they spent millions to make it.

Please do not waste your time and money cuz if you have a brain in your head you do not want to see this. I like fluff movies at times if there is at least some redeeming value to them ie laughs, action, visuals. This has none of the above. I used to love harrison ford but i'm starting to doubt the movies he picks cuz the last few i've seen have been pretty bad. Josh hartnett is no doubt a babe and i thought he was the only redeeming factor. Some people think he can't act but i think he's a pretty good actor and will be a big star. I look forward to see what he'll do in the future. Anyway, i've already seen beverly hills cop and this totally reminded me of that. The plotline was contrived, the big chase scene unoriginal, nothing you haven't seen 100 times before. Please spend your money on another good movie that's out so hollywood gets the message and stops putting out drivel like this. I'm going to see 28 days later tomorrow and i have high hopes for that cuz shallow grave & trainspotting rocked and so does christopher eccleston. I can already say i'm sure i'll enjoy it much more than hollywood homicide. PS. Please do not spend your money on charlie's angels either cuz i hope they don't make another one. I know that's selfish of me but oh well.

"Hollywood Homicide" sticks Ford and Hartnett as a pair LAPD homicide detectives in the middle of a mess of a movie involving some murders, an internal affairs investigation which connects with an external affair, moonlighting in real estate, yoga, and acting , and some love interest...yadayadayada. This lame comedy seems to get off on mixing the mundane moonlighting thing with cop stuff as though the "cops are people too" thing can be cranked into an eternal fountain of comedic creativity which, of course, it can't which, of course, is why this flick never really gets off the ground. Unfunny, undramatic, and ordinary in every way, "Hollywood Homicide" shoulda committed suicide and saved us all a some time and money. (C)

review_title: Both a good cop detective flick and a good action comedy
review_detailed_main:
I had no idea this was going to be as funny as it was. Dad and I went in expecting a serious detective flick about the seamy underbelly of the music biz. What we got was a good detective story about the aforementioned seamy underbelly and a helluva screwball comedy about two mismatched detectives and the troubles in their lives. Okay, the film is serious and violent at times so you might get a bit of whiplash as it switches from serious to comedy to serious again. But it's good whiplash.

Coming out of the flick, my eyes stung from all the laughing I did. And I was still giddy from the frequent andrenalin rushes. If movies are supposed to get you physically involved, this one succeeded.

Ford is quite enjoyable as the aging cop struggling to solve cases and make a fortune in legal second jobs. The problem is, other cops are not quite so picky where their second incomes come from. Hartnett is the young cop who is seems to be possessed by Shirley MacLaine. Lena Olin is quite fun as Rose, the radio psychic and Ford's girlfriend. Martin Landau is fun to watch as the aging film producer wanting to sell his mansion and maybe become a big name again.

The cast is full of people doing wonderful little cameo bits. Eric Idle starts of the parade as a writer protesting "I did not hire prostitutes! That was research! Oh, hi, Candy!" Lou Diamond Philips is gorgeous in drag as an undercover vice cop working a decoy stakeout. Singers Gladys Knight, Smokey Robinson, Dwight Yoakam and Frank Sinatra Junior all appear fleetingly (it was fun listening to the ladies behind me recognize her). And Robert Wagner is there basically to get a metaphorical creme pie in the face, but what the heck, you learn why Graumann's has that handprints in cement tradition! I have no idea why he's credited as "Silk Brown" though, as he is playing himself.

While I can't stand cell phones myself, they are used to great comic effect in two scenes. And after watching all the ultra-grim Internal Affairs scenes on NYPD BLUE, it was a real hoot watching the simultaneous interrogations of Ford's and Hartnett's characters go completely awry.

My rating-- this is worth full price.

review_title: Less than the sum of it's parts.
When are we gonna see some gratuitous sex,violence and language on our screens again?

review_detailed_main:
Following on their successful collaboration in this summer's blockbuster "Hollywood Homicide" Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett are going to release a 'crossover' album of the rap/hip-hop/house music genre.

It will feature brand new songs such as "Horribly MisKast" "Kissing my Chances for an Oscar Goodbye," "That Damn Ben Affleck gets all the Media Attention and J-Lo too" and the classic "Who is the Bigger Fool (My Agent or Me for Accepting This Role)?"

You will also be dancing with your sweetheart beneath the mirror ball to the slow tune "Donuts and Vitamin V...A tribute to over the hill action star."

Also, Smokey Robinson and Gladys Knight will be performing back up vocals, with Ludcris, Snoop Doggie, R Kelly and P Diddy on Violin, Cello, oboe and soup can, respectively.

Special appearances by Grouch Marx, Karl Marx, Bruce Greenwood, Mark Hamill, Hillary Clinton and Scott Peterson have been rumored but are unconfirmed at this time.

Ron Shelton is a clever and literate filmmaker who, at the top of his game, can transcend the trappings of genre ("Tin Cup," "Bull Durham," "Blaze"). That said, this cop-buddy-action-comedy is as generic as they come, and real junk. It paces feebly through every cliché, from the "cute" avocations of the partners (the older one sells real estate on the side, the younger one wants to be Brando) to the "funny" running gags (the young one's effortless studliness, the old one's cell phone with a "cute" ring) to the needless backstory (the younger one's dad was killed by one of the bad guys) to the pointless cameo guest stars (Gladys Knight, Smokey Robinson -- who are still welcome presences). And the women's roles! Sheer sex objects with no dimension; can this be the same Ron Shelton who wrote Susan Sarandon's great part in "Bull Durham"? The stunt doubles work overtime, the third-act car chase grinds on relentlessly, the bad guys have no edge or personality, the outcome isn't in doubt for a moment. Shelton's buddy banter is still a degree or two above the norm for this tired formula, and Ford paces with movie-star professionalism through the predictable trappings. As for Hartnett, why he's a movie star is never made clear.

review_title: How did this thing get made?
review_detailed_main:
Yes, this is a Harrison Ford movie. No, this is not a good movie.

I went into this with low expectations. Not low enough. I thought Josh Hartnett was ok in Black Hawk Down. He is not ok in this, mind you, he and Ford have very little to work with.

Read this and believe it: do not see this movie, do not rent it, do not watch it late at night if it's the only thing on TV, DO NOT.

This movie was very funny, and exceded my expectations with all of the special effects, and cutesy scenes. It is a must see! It is amazing how funny Josh Hartnett and Harrison Ford can be when they are in the same movie. I give this movie a 9 out of 10.

review_title: This is an amazingly bad movie...
review_detailed_main:
for all involved. Script cannot make up it's mind if it is a "buddy" movie, a comedy, police action film, so it turns out to be nothing but a mess.

There is absolutely no chemistry between Ford and Hartnett(who continues to give one wooden performance after another). I realize that Ford is supposed to be the older, grissled veteran, but to me, he played it too old to make it believable. His big chase scene is laughable, especially when he gets on the girls bike.

Everything about this movie is bad. Even the make-up. Did anyone else notice that Lena Olin's make-up was so heavy on her forehead and around her eyes, it made her look as if it had been applied by a cosmetoligist at a funeral home.

2 stars out of 10

review_title: I'd rather just watch "Lethal Weapon" again...
Hackneyed and cliched waste of time
