review_detailed_main: This movie is neither 1.)original, 2.)funny, 3.)suspenseful, or 4.)interesting. It lacks in everything it tries vainly to deliver. In fact, this movie leads me to believe that there is a script salvage yard in Hollywood, where bits and pieces from other dismal buddy/cop/drama films can be sewn together to thus create a tangible blob of moving pictures that everyone has seen before. Ultimately this is where the tragedy lies: We didn't like those other movies the first time around.

Just saw this movie and it was just what I needed. A very funny Harrison Ford, plays it for laughs. He is very good at comedy...surprisingly as he's usually very stoic and non-expressive in his movies. Josh Hartnett is also very good. A great movie with lots of unexpected cameos.

review_title: Deserves More Credit Than It Is Receiving
review_detailed_main: There were reports that the studio considered scrapping "Hollywood Homicide" because early returns on it were not favorable, but it was a very pleasant surprise. Harrison Ford hasn't done a lot of work lately, and most of it has not lived up to his high standards- it was good to see he's still got it. Josh Hartnett has not been a favorite, preferring to take on fluffy roles like the one he had in "Pearl Harbor," among other things. But he, as much if not more than Ford, is responsible for this movie's enjoyable storyline, which represents a revival of the "buddy" film with a new take on it- it's a fast-paced, masked comedy, and one that should not be raking in 1/100th of what "The Hulk" is taking in this week.

This movie is based on a highly trained cop whos partner is with a rookie. They both portray other occupations such as Harrisons character is a laugh out loud real estate broker who gives every minute trying to sell a house while Harnett's character plays a yoga instrcutor and also somewhat of a playboy. The movie made me laugh and gave me something more to enjoy than other action comedies such as Rush Hour.I recommend this movie.

The film has something that holds you in your seat for the entire. Maybe because this movie is somewhat more of a success in laughter than Rush Hour, most likely not at the box office. Harrison Fords character plays a cop who is greatly in debt and also holds a job as a real estate desperatley trying to sell a house and turn a quick profit. His rookie partner who plays a yoga teacher and somewhat also a ladies man who wants to get out of the business and become a actor mainly because he just cant take the job anymore. They investigate a crime that they are trying to figure out who murdered four sensation rap singers. I would agreed with the comment of Mr. Ebert and Mr. Roeper completley on what they said about this film. This movie I found that liked it right in the beginning. This movie is just a great way to start your summer off with some decent action-comedy to have you buzzing about all summer. Finally a pair of partners that I could finally get use to.

I was stunned by the outcome of this film.A highly trained is partners with a rookie. Fords character plays a detective and a real estate agent. He spends the duration of the film trying to sell a house for a quick little profit. Harnett's character is a playboy which he also is a detective and a yoga instrcutor. Where they try to find the mastermind behind a number hits on rappers. I spent the entire of the film laughing and cutting to this little quick-witted film. This film was a more promising movie such other than action-comedies such as Rush Hour. I could defaulty sum this entire movie really into one SEE!

I saw a sneak preview of this movie was very pleased. I'm a big fan of Harrison Ford and it was great just to see him in another movie, but him and Josh Hartnett seemed to work really well together. The whole audience was laughing for the majority of the entire movie. All in all, this was definately worth seeing.

I must say though that the pace seems to slow down somewhere in the first quarter of the movie, and I was afraid things wouldn't pick up, but luckily they did and the rest of the movie totally made up for this. Also, there did seem to be somewhat a lack of resolution at the end but nowhere to the degree where I felt jipped or anything. I still felt a nice resolution at the end.

But as I said, these complaints are definately outweighed by the rest of the movie which is thoroughly enjoyable. 8 out of 10 stars here.

review_title: don't take it too seriously, and you'll like it
review_detailed_main: *** out of 4 Homicide starts out slow but once you catch on, you'll see it's not an ordinary buddy cop movie. In contrast to the movies and TV shows we see way too often with mismatched cops who take their jobs way too seriously to provide good entertainment (Training Day, Showtime, Narc, Recruit, Third Watch, NYPD Blue, etc), this film is about two cops who are good at what they do but couldn't care less. Set in a city where everyone aspires to be something other than what they are, Josh Hartnett's K.C. Calden wants to be an actor while Harrison Ford's Joe Gavilan would rather be in real estate. Tied into the title, this premise cleverly pokes fun at its subjects' lives and subtly provides some genuine humor. Ford plays his role with far less intensity than you'd expect. Some might think he's sleepwalking through the script, and you can't deny that he doesn't put much effort to act like anyone other than himself, but the bottom line, is that a lazy Harrison Ford is fun to watch irreguardless.

Hollywood Homicide is well worth seeing. One could start with analyzing the title and end up with criticizing the driving, but are these really what make the audience like or dislike a movie? They are not, in my humble opinion. Remember that if your horizon of expectations is not met, this is reason enough to chew on what you have just watched. To me, this movie was unexpected. While others may want to call it a bad detective movie, I like to call it a lovely comedy, a parody of both Hollywood industry and the police world. While Josh Hartnett can be unexpected in many of his roles, Harrison Ford really outdid himself playing such a part. So people, if you want to unwind after a bad or tiresome day, do watch this one. It's underrated!

i totally have to say that josh hartnett does an amazing job on this movie! not to say that he is a total hunk! and i was on the movie set and got to hang out with him and hes really nice which makes him a even better actor because he doesn't have a big ego. This movie is a great comedy but yet there's suspense!Its a good movie to watch with friends, under 13 parents make have to skip a few scenes for violence and sex related matters . Other than that they did a great job with the movie! This movie is a great family film (for older kids that is) and is a lot of fun. Plus it takes place in Hollywood which makes it very interesting. review_title: Glad I gave this movie a chance
Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett are quite a Pair
If you've ever moonlighted as a realtor you will love this movie!
review_detailed_main: I love this movie. When I was selling software ( a job that gives you much freedom), I too sold high end real estate, not as high as Joe, but I, too, found myself taking phone calls during dinners, parties, house guests, etc. I have seen realtors who got themselves into horrible real estate investments that were similar to those of this movies heroes. And the reactions are all the same as portrayed in this film. While it seems a little far fetched I assure you it is not. Harrison Ford plays the cop who gets himself into all kinds of trouble from imminent foreclosure, repossession of his auto and complications in his love life. Watch it to laugh at this close to life example when one occupation collides with another.

review_title: A fun disappointment, but a disappointment nonetheless

review_detailed_main:
Hollywood Homicide was made for the hartnett loving, car chases are cool too, don't-care-much-about-the-plot-just-as-long-as-it's-josh teenage girls.

Which is why it is my favorite summer movie so far. It is a pretty good movie about different age groups clashing and being drawn together over common intrests (like women). Most of the movie is headshots of Josh, but it's not like I'm complaining...

While watching Hollywood Homicide I couldn't help but feel like Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett probably had a good deal of fun making the movie, and certainly a good deal of this fun is shared by the audience. Ford here reminds me of his appearances on Late Night with Conan O'Brian, a times reserved yet sprinkled with burst of manic silliness. He is downright funny in this role and I was surprised at how much I liked the on-screen coupling of Ford and Hartnett. The rest of the movie, however, seemed like it had been written much too hastily. The concept is a good one - cops in L.A. often have second jobs to supplement their income - and it is fairly well executed, yet the quadruple homicide plot seems to be secondary to the shenanigans of the characters. The movie seems to want to be Lethal Weapon, but can't find a comfortable rhythm. At times it felt like entire scenes were missing, as if there'd been some mistake in the projection booth, that's how badly the movie flowed. Overall, however, the performances make the movie an enjoyable one and worth a look.

"Hollywood Homicide" is a movie starring Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett as detectives Joe Gavilan and K. C. Calden, assigned to Hollywood. Galivan, preoccupied with his real estate business, attempts to sell a house to a club owner who has just been killed. Calden, who wants to be an actor, has Galivan run lines from "A Streetcar Named Desire." The movie was directed by Ron Shelton, who co-wrote with Robert Souza and specializes in funny dialogue for guy characters. The movie is more interested in the goofy cops than the murder plot, with their dialogue redeeming otherwise standard scenes. The movie features a double act between a man who has seen everything and a man who has seen too much. K. C., who moonlights as a yoga instructor, agrees that they are all going to die someday, but his philosophical observations are cut short by a crash. The movie "Hollywood Homicide" begins with a hit on a rap group in a music club, resulting in four deaths. Joe and K. C. investigate, but are under investigation by Benne Macko, the Internal Affairs guy who hates Joe. Joe is suspected of "mingling funds," confusing his personal debts with his real estate business debts. He has been seen with Ferre Salesclerk, a known hooker, and Ruby the psychic (Lena Olin), another member of the Los Angeles women who believe it is fun to make love on a blanket in an empty house. Hartnett makes an able partner for Ford, trading deadpan dialogue and telling everyone he's an actor. He has one of Shelton's nicest little scenes when he goes to the morgue and looks at the dead bodies of the murder victims. There is a chase and a half at the end of the movie, filled with cameos and walk-bys, including Frank Sinatra Jr. As a show-biz lawyer, Martin Landau as a fading producer, Lou Diamond Phillips as Wanda the cop in drag, Gladys Knight, Dwight Yoakam, Isaiah Washington, Master P, Kurupt, Eric Idle, Dr. Dre, and just plain Dre. Much of the closing excitement depends on the Fallacy of the Climbing Killer, a dependable chase cliche where the killer climbs to a high place from which he cannot escape unless he can fly. This film may be the most exciting film ever made about real estate, with the dialogue being the reason to see the movie. The movie is filled with cameos and walk-bys, and the dialogue is the reason to see the movie.
